title: UX Mindsets: Fixed Versus Growth
description: Embrace adaptability in UX: reframe challenges, balance research with action, and foster a growth mindset to keep up with this evolving industry.
author: Alita Kendrick
excerpt: Embrace adaptability in UX: reframe challenges, balance research with action, and foster a growth mindset to keep up with this evolving industry.
text: Summary:  Embrace adaptability in UX: reframe challenges, balance research with action, and foster a growth mindset to keep up with this evolving industry. Our industry is consistently evolving, with new methods, tools, and technologies emerging rapidly. As a result, adaptability has become an essential skill for the modern UX professional. The way we think and our internal monologues or mindsets influence our behavior.  Identifying Mindset Patterns In UX Work Fixed Mindset Indicators and Reframing to Growth Striking the Right Mindset Balance Identifying Mindset Patterns In UX Work Which of the following mindsets do you align more with? Mindset 1 Mindset 2 My UX skills are fundamental to who I am and are unlikely to change much over time. I can learn new UX methods, but my natural ability in UX design or research is mostly set. With experience and effort, I can expand and refine my UX expertise. I believe my ability to solve UX challenges can grow significantly with practice, feedback, and learning. Dr. Carol Dweck’s research shows that our beliefs about intelligence and ability shape our behavior, performance, and adaptability. Through her work, she identified two primary mindsets. Fixed Mindset (mindset 1 noted above): The belief that intelligence and ability are static, which leads individuals to avoid challenges and feedback that might threaten their self-perception. Growth Mindset (mindset 2 noted above): The belief that intelligence and abilities can be developed through effort, learning, and persistence, which encourages adaptability and resilience.  Her research shows that a growth mindset fosters better learning outcomes, greater resilience, and a willingness to take on new challenges – qualities that are essential in UX teams.  Fixed Mindset Indicators and Reframing to Growth Teams with fixed mindsets can create blockers for creativity, hinder cross-functional collaboration, and stifle product innovation. Watch out for these common indicators.  Resistance to Change and Innovation “We've always done it this way, and it works fine." "I’ve been doing UX for years; I don’t need to learn a new way of doing things." "New tools just complicate things—let’s stick to what we know." Does this sound familiar? Individuals and teams with fixed mindsets might resist new design trends, tools, or methods because they believe what they know is already sufficient. For example, avoiding experimenting with generative AI for your UX workflows might be a sign that you’re resistant to change in general). Resistance to change isn’t just about tools; it can also show up when you’re facing process changes. For example, when a new way of tracking work is introduced (I know, sometimes I roll my eyes, too), it can be tempting to dismiss it by saying, "Nothing’s really going to change, so why switch things up?" However, sometimes these minor workflow changes can improve teamwork, efficiency, and visibility. Instead of defaulting to skepticism (which can be an endearing personality trait, but may lead to a toxic work environment), try adopting a growth mindset. Catch yourself in these thought traps and reframe them. Ask yourself: "What’s one way I can test this out?” “How might this improve our process over time?” Even if a new tool or process isn’t perfect (they rarely are), embracing experimentation helps UX teams stay adaptive, competitive, and continuously improve.  Poor Feedback Culture and Defensive Design Critiques "That’s just your opinion. I think the design works fine." "We’ve already put so much work into this; changing it now doesn’t make sense." "I spent weeks on this, and now you’re telling me it’s wrong?!" Team members with a fixed mindset often take feedback personally, viewing critiques as attacks on their competence. I get it — receiving feedback can be tough. But when constructive input is dismissed or deflected, it creates tension and leads to unproductive design reviews, stalling iteration, and reduced product improvement. Dismissing feedback, taking it personally, deflecting or avoiding accountability, and rejecting constructive criticism foster a poor feedback culture. Over time, these create friction within teams, hinder iteration, and result in missed opportunities for innovation.  If an entire UX team develops a reputation for defensiveness, it can seriously undermine its organizational influence. Especially in companies with low UX maturity, other departments may avoid UX involvement to prevent anticipated friction. This can lead to a vicious cycle where UX is gradually excluded from key decisions, consulted too late in the process to make meaningful contributions, or its input is solicited merely as a formality rather than valued expertise. If receiving feedback feels like a personal attack, reframe it as a means to improvement. Seek out additional clarification instead of shutting down. Adopt a curious mindset and aim to test out feedback more than reject it. Even when feedback is difficult to hear, take a deep breath and approach it with a solution-oriented approach.  Risk Aversion in Design Decisions and Over-Reliance on Research "If we push for something new and it fails, leadership won’t trust us next time." "Let’s not make any changes until we run another round of usability testing." "We can’t move forward without more stakeholder alignment and research." If research frequently becomes a bottleneck, or you hesitate to take risks in low-stakes situations, you may have a fixed mindset. While data-driven decisions and research are essential to good UX, an excessive focus on gaining certainty over taking action can lead to paralysis when you need progress.  When teams avoid risk and refuse to move forward without perfect data, it can result in slow iterations, overcomplicated decision making, missed innovation opportunities, and lack of differentiation. Find a healthy balance between research and experimentation and recognize that not every decision needs exhaustive validation before moving forward. Don’t fear failure and embrace learning through trial and iteration. Striking the Right Mindset Balance Too much of a good thing can be bad. A growth mindset doesn’t mean blindly embracing every new method, tool, or technology without critical thinking. It also doesn’t mean avoiding expertise or best practices. The goal is to strike a balance between adaptability and strategic thinking.  Conclusion If this article felt like a targeted attack on the way you think about UX, take it as a wake-up call rather than a condemnation. How will you respond the next time you face a challenge opportunity?  We recommend that you: Recognize your fixed mindset-tendencies Experiment with new approaches, even if they feel uncomfortable Reframe feedback as a tool for growth Balance research with action References Dweck, C. html:
Summary:  Embrace adaptability in UX: reframe challenges, balance research with action, and foster a growth mindset to keep up with this evolving industry.

Our industry is consistently evolving, with new methods, tools, and technologies emerging rapidly. As a result, adaptability has become an essential skill for the modern UX professional. The way we think and our internal monologues or mindsets influence our behavior. 

  • Identifying Mindset Patterns In UX Work
  • Fixed Mindset Indicators and Reframing to Growth
  • Striking the Right Mindset Balance

Identifying Mindset Patterns In UX Work

Which of the following mindsets do you align more with?

Mindset 1 Mindset 2

My UX skills are fundamental to who I am and are unlikely to change much over time.

I can learn new UX methods, but my natural ability in UX design or research is mostly set.

With experience and effort, I can expand and refine my UX expertise.

I believe my ability to solve UX challenges can grow significantly with practice, feedback, and learning.

Dr. Carol Dweck’s research shows that our beliefs about intelligence and ability shape our behavior, performance, and adaptability. Through her work, she identified two primary mindsets.

  • Fixed Mindset (mindset 1 noted above): The belief that intelligence and ability are static, which leads individuals to avoid challenges and feedback that might threaten their self-perception.
  • Growth Mindset (mindset 2 noted above): The belief that intelligence and abilities can be developed through effort, learning, and persistence, which encourages adaptability and resilience. 

Her research shows that a growth mindset fosters better learning outcomes, greater resilience, and a willingness to take on new challenges – qualities that are essential in UX teams. 

Fixed Mindset Indicators and Reframing to Growth

Teams with fixed mindsets can create blockers for creativity, hinder cross-functional collaboration, and stifle product innovation. Watch out for these common indicators. 

Resistance to Change and Innovation

“We've always done it this way, and it works fine."

"I’ve been doing UX for years; I don’t need to learn a new way of doing things."

"New tools just complicate things—let’s stick to what we know."

Does this sound familiar? Individuals and teams with fixed mindsets might resist new design trends, tools, or methods because they believe what they know is already sufficient. For example, avoiding experimenting with generative AI for your UX workflows might be a sign that you’re resistant to change in general).

Resistance to change isn’t just about tools; it can also show up when you’re facing process changes. For example, when a new way of tracking work is introduced (I know, sometimes I roll my eyes, too), it can be tempting to dismiss it by saying, "Nothing’s really going to change, so why switch things up?" However, sometimes these minor workflow changes can improve teamwork, efficiency, and visibility.

Instead of defaulting to skepticism (which can be an endearing personality trait, but may lead to a toxic work environment), try adopting a growth mindset. Catch yourself in these thought traps and reframe them. Ask yourself:

"What’s one way I can test this out?”

“How might this improve our process over time?”

Even if a new tool or process isn’t perfect (they rarely are), embracing experimentation helps UX teams stay adaptive, competitive, and continuously improve. 

Poor Feedback Culture and Defensive Design Critiques

"That’s just your opinion. I think the design works fine."

"We’ve already put so much work into this; changing it now doesn’t make sense."

"I spent weeks on this, and now you’re telling me it’s wrong?!"

Team members with a fixed mindset often take feedback personally, viewing critiques as attacks on their competence. I get it — receiving feedback can be tough. But when constructive input is dismissed or deflected, it creates tension and leads to unproductive design reviews, stalling iteration, and reduced product improvement.

Dismissing feedback, taking it personally, deflecting or avoiding accountability, and rejecting constructive criticism foster a poor feedback culture. Over time, these create friction within teams, hinder iteration, and result in missed opportunities for innovation. 

If an entire UX team develops a reputation for defensiveness, it can seriously undermine its organizational influence. Especially in companies with low UX maturity, other departments may avoid UX involvement to prevent anticipated friction. This can lead to a vicious cycle where UX is gradually excluded from key decisions, consulted too late in the process to make meaningful contributions, or its input is solicited merely as a formality rather than valued expertise.

If receiving feedback feels like a personal attack, reframe it as a means to improvement. Seek out additional clarification instead of shutting down. Adopt a curious mindset and aim to test out feedback more than reject it. Even when feedback is difficult to hear, take a deep breath and approach it with a solution-oriented approach. 

Risk Aversion in Design Decisions and Over-Reliance on Research

"If we push for something new and it fails, leadership won’t trust us next time."

"Let’s not make any changes until we run another round of usability testing."

"We can’t move forward without more stakeholder alignment and research."

If research frequently becomes a bottleneck, or you hesitate to take risks in low-stakes situations, you may have a fixed mindset. While data-driven decisions and research are essential to good UX, an excessive focus on gaining certainty over taking action can lead to paralysis when you need progress. 

When teams avoid risk and refuse to move forward without perfect data, it can result in slow iterations, overcomplicated decision making, missed innovation opportunities, and lack of differentiation. Find a healthy balance between research and experimentation and recognize that not every decision needs exhaustive validation before moving forward. Don’t fear failure and embrace learning through trial and iteration.

Striking the Right Mindset Balance

Too much of a good thing can be bad. A growth mindset doesn’t mean blindly embracing every new method, tool, or technology without critical thinking. It also doesn’t mean avoiding expertise or best practices. The goal is to strike a balance between adaptability and strategic thinking. 

Conclusion

If this article felt like a targeted attack on the way you think about UX, take it as a wake-up call rather than a condemnation. How will you respond the next time you face a challenge opportunity? 

We recommend that you:

  • Recognize your fixed mindset-tendencies
  • Experiment with new approaches, even if they feel uncomfortable
  • Reframe feedback as a tool for growth
  • Balance research with action

References

Dweck, C. S. 2016. Mindset: The New Psychology of Success. Updated edition. Random House, New York.
